summaries.body: An arrest warrant was issued in Australia for a doctor, believed to be in Syria, who appeared in an Islamic State recruitment video.
South Korean lawmakers approved a new prime minister, weeks after the last one stepped down over allegations that he had accepted illegal campaign donations.
Chinese companies that build civilian ships will be required to ensure that the military can use them in an emergency, a state-run newspaper reported.

posts.footer: A reporter for the Post and Courier in Charleston, S.C., where the police reported that a shooting had taken place in a downtown church, via Twitter

summaries.body: Dramatic pic by @MatthewFortner of search for gunman in downtown Charleston. #chsnews http://t.co/h7vFO5sVK3
A drug for dwarfism improved growth in children by a significant amount in a preliminary study, its developer said. No treatment for the condition has ever been approved.
A military jury found a Marine sergeant guilty of murder in the retrial of a major Iraq war-crimes case involving the 2006 killing of an Iraqi man.
Fitbit, the fitness-tracking device maker, priced its I.P.O. at $20 a share, valuing the company at $4.1 billion.
The mayor of Spokane, Wash., called for Rachel Dolezal, the former N.A.A.C.P. leader, and two others to resign from the city’s Office of the Police Ombudsman commission.
Foster Farms, a chicken plant in California, suspended five workers after a graphic video purporting to show inhumane slaughter practices was released.
A California judge said Ellen Pao, a former partner at Kleiner Perkins, owes the venture capital firm $276,000 in legal costs related to her unsuccessful discrimination lawsuit.
Airbnb, the housing rental service, is in talks to raise $1 billion in venture capital, a person close to the discussions said. The financing round would value it at $24 billion.
The number of new H.I.V. cases in a rural Indiana county that has seen a recent epidemic has fallen drastically, public health officials said.
Apple's new streaming music service, set to arrive on June 30, has already upset independent record companies because of its proposed licensing terms.
The N.B.A. finals averaged 19.94 million viewers, the most-watched series since 1998, Michael Jordan's last season with the Chicago Bulls.
Melissa Rivers, right, will co-host "Fashion Police," the E! show hosted by her mother, Joan Rivers, until she died last year.
Officials ordered the inspection of ventilation systems in train tunnels nationwide after a smoke-filled tunnel in Washington caused a passenger's death in January.
Muse, the arena-filling British band, topped the Billboard album chart for the first time with its new album, "Drones."
A time capsule placed by Paul Revere and Samuel Adams in 1795, added to in 1855 and found last year was returned to the Massachusetts Statehouse with new tokens.

display_asset.caption: Jeb Bush at a campaign event in Washington, Iowa, on Wednesday.

summaries.body: Jeb Bush backed away from criticizing Pope Francis on climate change but did assert that global warming is a threat and the federal government should address it.

posts.footer: Cleveland quarterback Johnny Manziel, in his first comments since a stint in rehab, on the hype of his nickname and a disappointing rookie season, via The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer

summaries.body: I think at times Johnny Football probably took over me a little bit, and I bought into that.
A taco, a unicorn and a bag of popcorn are among the new emoji characters that could soon be coming to phones. The taco, in particular, has long been requested.
Federal prosecutors won't bring criminal charges after an inquiry into loans made by Kansas' lieutenant governor to the re-election campaign of Gov. Sam Brownback.
Ed Balls, a top leader in Britain's Labour Party who lost his seat in May's general election, will join Harvard University as a senior fellow to research financial stability.
A cyberattack disabled Canadian government websites and email on Wednesday. "There's only sporadic emails that are making their way through," an official said.

display_asset.credit: Jacob Hannah for The New York Times

summaries.body: Joyce Mitchell, the prison worker charged with helping two New York inmates escape, had discussed with them a murder-for-hire plot against her husband, a prosecutor said.
A new Human Rights Watch report said torture and abuse are rampant in prisons controlled by Libya's internationally recognized government and allied forces.
Arturo Vidal, the Copa América's leading scorer and star midfielder for Chile, appeared in court after he smashed his Ferrari and was arrested on an intoxicated-driving charge.
The Federal Communications Commission said AT&T Inc. would be fined $100 million for misleading customers about unlimited mobile data plans.
Federal regulators expect to finalize rules within a year to allow U.S. companies like Amazon to start using commercial drones for their business operations, an official said.
Goldman Sachs has told its summer investment banking interns not to stay in the office overnight in a bid to improve working conditions for its junior staff.
A town in Pennsylvania has agreed to pay $650,000 to the family of an 89-year-old woman who was mistakenly shot dead by the police during a gun battle with a suspect.
Walmart Stores owns more than $76 billion of assets through units in offshore tax havens around the world, a report said. A spokesman said the report was misleading.
The Chinese government gave more details of its building work in disputed parts of the South China Sea, listing lighthouses, communications stations and other facilities.
Pope Francis, in his weekly general audience, urged governments to act together to prevent forced migration. Above, Coast Guard officers helped migrants in Greece.
FedEx, the operator of the world’s largest cargo airline, posted a fourth-quarter profit of $753 million, or $2.66 a share, trailing analysts' estimates.
Hong Kong’s Legislative Council began debate on a plan to change the way the semiautonomous Chinese territory will choose its leader beginning in 2017.
The governor of Greece’s central bank, Yannis Stournaras, said his country faces an “uncontrollable crisis” if a deal on bailout funds cannot be reached.

display_asset.caption: The bust of Pope Paul V (1621), by Bernini.

summaries.body: The J. Paul Getty Museum has just acquired an important early sculpture by Bernini: a marble bust of Pope Paul V that many art historians did not believe still existed.
The Royal Bank of Scotland said that about 600,000 customer transactions had not been processed as a result of a technology failure overnight.
A man hitting people with a brick at a station in Xi’an, China, was killed by the police, a railway police blog post said. It later deleted the detail that he was an ethnic Uighur.
U.S. stock index futures rose ahead of a Federal Reserve announcement on interest rates, which the central bank's policy makers are expected to leave unchanged.
An escaped zoo tiger was shot dead in Tbilisi, Georgia, after it killed a man working on flood relief, a spokeswoman said. Earlier reports said the animal was a lion.
A British sailor who published an online document claiming that Britain's nuclear-armed submarines have major security flaws is no longer with the navy, a spokesman said.
Banks in Switzerland have reported 53 possible acts of money laundering in the investigation of FIFA's 2018 and 2022 World Cup bidding contests, the attorney general said.
The World Health Organization said that the spread of Middle East respiratory system is "a wake-up call," but that it has not reached the level of a global emergency.
A lawmaker in Nauru said he was removed from a plane and prevented from leaving the Pacific island nation, a day after a fellow member of the opposition was arrested.

display_asset.caption: A nurse seen through a door as she talked with a patient at Beijing You'an Hospital.

summaries.body: A Chinese nurse's resignation letter, posted online, drew attention to the harsher side of the job in the country, including exhaustion, harassment and the threat of violence.
The French environment minister, Ségolène Royal, has urged the public to stop eating Nutella, which contains palm oil, saying it contributes to deforestation.
Airstrikes hit military targets throughout Yemen and expanded into one western province for the first time, despite peace talks in Geneva.
More than 450 journalists, nearly a quarter of them from Syria, have been forced into exile since 2010, the Committee to Protect Journalists said.
Japan's Parliament passed legislation lowering the voting age to 18, from 20.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent in Hong Kong, where protesters gathered as the Legislative Council prepared to debate a Beijing-approved plan for electing the city's leader, via Twitter

summaries.body: Gathering of the pro-Beijing clans outside Legco in Hong Kong. THERE CAN BE ONLY ONE http://t.co/4pP2MbavEk
Amnesty International accused Myanmar of threatening, harassing and imprisoning journalists as national elections approach this year.

posts.footer: A statement from Neil Young's team, which added that the Canadian musician supports Senator Bernie Sanders for president, via The New York Times

summaries.body: Donald Trump was not authorized to use ‘Rockin’ in the Free World’ in his presidential candidacy announcement.

posts.footer: The Australian Broadcasting Corporation | The Associated Press

summaries.body: Australia signed a free trade agreement with China, as its trade minister warned that the United States had little time to salvage a broader Asia-Pacific accord.
Vietnam accused China of intercepting two Vietnamese fishing boats and using water cannon against a third in disputed South China Sea waters.
Canada's top military officer apologized for saying that sexual harassment in the military was due in part to how offenders are "biologically wired."
Joe Paterno, the Penn State coach who was fired amid a child sex abuse scandal at the university, was posthumously elected to the Pennsylvania Sports Hall of Fame.
The U.S. plans to provide $5 million to help support a regional military force fighting Boko Haram, the Islamist militant group in Nigeria, a State Department official said.
Gov. Jerry Brown and California lawmakers announced a budget deal that extends public health care coverage to immigrant children who are in the country illegally.
The world's largest underground aquifers, a source of fresh water, are being depleted at alarming rates, according to new NASA satellite data.
A college student in Queens was charged with conspiring to support the Islamic State after an investigation found he planned to attack New York City landmarks.
A decline in egg production by 341 million dozen this year is expected to mean a wholesale price of $1.60 to $1.66 for a dozen New York large eggs, a record high.

posts.footer: A Times columnist, via Twitter. The U.S. plays Nigeria at 8 p.m. Eastern in the Women's World Cup.

summaries.body: Alex Morgan starts her 1st game at this World Cup. Is she 90-minutes ready? Let's see in a few. Abby Wambach, a sub last game, is a starter.
While it prevailed in its legal argument, Maurice R. Greenberg's firm still thinks the government owes money to A.I.G. shareholders.
U.S. officials proposed declaring the eastern cougar to be extinct. Officials said they most likely have been for at least 70 years but were listed as endangered in 1973.
President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said the national unity government he formed with Hamas last year would dissolve. He did not give a timetable.
21st Century Fox announced that Rupert Murdoch's two sons would assume new leadership roles, continuing plans to keep control of the company in the family.
The Foo Fighters have canceled the remainder of their European tour after Dave Grohl, the band's frontman, fell and broke his leg at a show on June 12 in Sweden.
Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., came out as gay Tuesday, writing in a newspaper that it took him years to accept that his sexuality is just "part of who I am."

display_asset.credit: Jason Minto/The Wilmington News-Journal, via The A.P.

summaries.body: Molly Shattuck, a former Baltimore Ravens cheerleader, pleaded guilty to fourth-degree rape. She was accused of having a relationship with a 15-year-old boy.
Among its announcements at the E3 conference, Nintendo said Super Mario Maker, which allows gamers to craft their own Super Mario levels, will arrive on Sept. 11.
BBC said Chris Evans would be the new "Top Gear" host, taking over for Jeremy Clarkson on the popular car show.
The HBO show “Game of Thrones” set a series record for total viewers with its season finale Sunday night with 8.1 million viewers, according to Nielsen.
Twitter’s departing chief executive officer, Dick Costolo, said he is confident about its current strategy and team, but his replacement should have the leeway to make changes.
Boston 2024, the private group organizing the city’s bid to host the 2024 Summer Olympics, is offering a new plan that spreads the events across Massachusetts.

display_asset.credit: Rachel Denny Clow/Corpus Christi Caller-TImes, via Associated Press

summaries.body: A tropical storm has started to make landfall along the Texas coast, bringing torrential rain and possible flooding as it moves north. It is forecast to reach Dallas on Wednesday.
Omar Gonzalez, an Army veteran from Texas, was sentenced to 17 months in prison for jumping the White House fence and entering the East Room in September.
United Airlines said it would move out of Kennedy International Airport this year and shift all of its flights to Los Angeles and San Francisco to its hub in Newark.
South Korea said it now has 154 Middle East respiratory syndrome cases, the largest outbreak outside of Saudi Arabia. Above, workers fumigate a theater.
Donald Trump announced that he is running for president: "We are going to make our country great again."
At least 17 people were killed and 70 were injured when a passenger train hit a truck and derailed at an unmarked crossing south of Tunisia's capital, officials said.
More than 23,000 new refugees fleeing recent fighting in northern Syria have crossed into Turkey, the United Nations refugee agency said, quoting Turkish authorities.
Thousands of villagers have evacuated but others are refusing to leave homes near Mount Sinabung in Indonesia, even as avalanches of hot ash barreled down its slopes.
The Food and Drug Administration said it would require food companies to phase out the use of artificial trans fats almost entirely, saying they are a public health concern.
Permits to build houses in the United States rose 11.8 percent in May to a 1.28 million annualized pace, the highest since August 2007, government figures showed.
Fitbit, the maker of wearable health-tracking devices, raised the range for the expected pricing of its initial public offering to $17 to $19 a share.
An 18-year-old German man was sentenced to three years in detention for hitting a woman, Tugce Albayrak, who fell and later died. She had tried to stop him harassing two girls.

posts.footer: A CNN media reporter on the former N.A.A.C.P. leader being interviewed by Matt Lauer on “Today."

summaries.body: Catchiest quote in @MLauer's Rachel Dolezal interview so far, about how her complexion's changed: "I... certainly don't stay out of the sun"
Prince Alwaleed bin Talal, a Saudi billionaire, said he settled a libel suit against the Forbes magazine group. He claimed the magazine underestimated his fortune.

display_asset.caption: Al Haj Murad Ebrahim, the head of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front, inspecting a rocket launcher at the handover in Sultan Kudarat, Philippines, on Tuesday. President Benigno S. Aquino III, far left, said: “Our brothers are voluntarily laying down their arms.”

summaries.body: Islamic militants in the southern Philippines turned over dozens of weapons as part of a tentative peace deal. A final agreement is facing resistance from lawmakers.
Michelle Obama, left, and her daughters are in Britain for a two-day trip to promote her charity work. She is scheduled to meet Prince Harry and have tea with the prime minister.
Bahrain has sentenced an opposition leader, Sheikh Ali Salman, to four years in prison on charges related to incitement against the ruling system, his party said.
A British referendum on E.U. membership will not be held on May 5, 2016, the same day as votes in Scotland and Wales, a victory for those who want to leave the bloc.
The far-right National Front in France said on Monday it had enough support to form a group in the European Parliament, a move that would increase its influence.

display_asset.caption: Banca Monte dei Paschi was founded in 1472. It has survived plagues, panics and wars, though perhaps not the financial hubris that led to its bailout.
display_asset.credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times

summaries.body: Monte dei Paschi, the world’s oldest bank, was the center of life in Siena, Italy, for centuries. So when it nearly collapsed, the city was left scrambling to fill the void.
Bangladesh's highest court upheld the death sentence given to an Islamist politician accused of atrocities during the country's war of independence in 1971.

posts.footer: H.R. Nagendra, a yoga consultant to Prime Minister Narendra Modi, describing the Indian leader's practice, via The New York Times

summaries.body: From one place to another place he will travel. During the travel, say half an hour, an hour — then he will relax, then he will remember the inner silence, the inner relaxation, the inner blissful awareness, and do the work.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent on reports that the leader of Al Qadea's Yemen affiliate was killed in an American drone strike, via Twitter

summaries.body: If Al Qaeda ideologue Abu Qatada is tweeting condolences for Wahashi's death, seems likely death is more than rumor https://t.co/uY6zHFmNW4
Israel released an animated video mocking Western coverage of the Gaza conflict last year, part of its effort to undermine potential criticism in a United Nations report.
